results.title: The Other Face of the Island
results.creator_credit: John M. Bale, Norman Laird, Tasfilm Productions and Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production
results.brief_description: Using special cinematograph effects such as split screens, this film sets up a storyline to promote the resources and industries of Tasmania. The main products and secondary industries are grouped broadly into wool and textiles, including carpets; paper; processed food; and metal products. The cast includes four Australian models - Wendy Gilmore, Nola Clark, Carol Stevens and Barbara Wilding - outfitted by Prue Acton.

results.title: On the ball (1st Version)
results.brief_description: A humorous commentary on the game of Australian football. Go there, see it all. The screams, the advice, friendly admonitions. An analysis of the various aspects of Australian Rules Football spectatorship.

results.title: Om and Prom from Cambodia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “My Friends”.
A day in the life of two Cambodian boys. Shows them at school, at play, at home and working in the rice fields. They ride on elephants to the ruins of Angkor where they see the age-old ritual of the beautiful palace dancers.

results.title: Noise destroys
results.creator_credit: Mike Woolveridge, Phillip Mark-Law, John Honey, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1979 film deals with the effects of industrial noise on hearing. Presented as a dramatic short film, the narrative follows the protagonist, Len, as he discovers he is partially deaf due to twenty years of working with loud machines in a factory and goes on a crusade to improve working conditions. The film is directed at employers as well as employees, showing the importance of wearing safety gear and machines being modified or insulated to limit sound production. The film contains light-hearted moments of comedy, as Len goes about convincing his colleagues and management of the significance of the issue.

Produced by the Tasmanian Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Max Cullen, Brian Duhig, Barry Pierce, John Hale, Keith Jarvis, Barrie Muir, Jack Perry, Richard Meredith, Billie Hammerberg, Tony Boden, Kevin Lacey, Don Glover, Tracy Lee, Bob Gunning, Peter Lewis, Matthew Rhodes

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: The Narwhals came
results.brief_description: Shows records of undersea life made by divers in Arctic waters. Includes photography of the Narwhal whale, sought by hunters for its prized ivory tusk.

results.title: A Moving Picture
results.creator_credit: John M. Bale and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the operation of air, sea, road and rail services in Tasmania, the important part they play in the State’s economy and the use made of them by local industries.

results.title: The Man on the beat
results.creator_credit: Patricia Murray, Ralph Kemplen, Roger MacDougall and Merlin Films
results.brief_description: The duties and training of a London policeman, known over the world for his courtesy. The London policeman is unarmed, and his duties vary from finding lost children to directing traffic. Dealing with crime is only an occasional part of the ordinary London policeman’s job.

results.title: Listen to a city
results.creator_credit: Eric Fullilove, Andrew J. Helgeson and Cinesound
results.brief_description: A sophisticated view of Melbourne taking in its gardens, shops, theatres, restaurants, nightclubs and discotheques. Sporting activities include a race meeting, a football match, and water sports. Highlights Melbourne’s annual Moombe Festival and includes scenes at Montsalvat.

results.title: Light play: black-white-gray = Ein lightspiel: scwarz-weiss-grau
results.brief_description: Moholy-Nagy, an exponent of modern design in architecture, painting, theatre and typography, illustrates the forms and relationships of his constructivist art. Constructions of steel, glass and wire, including the artist’s light-space modulator, move, merge and dissolve to produce a world of interrelated shapes and patterns. Surface textures, spatial tensions and shadows are combined with the resources of the film cameras - super- impositions, positive-negative contrasts and trick effects to produce rhythms in light, shade, space and movement.

results.title: Kip and David. Episode 04
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Kip and David”.
David and his elfin friend Kip discover many surprises while playing in the garden. A green tree frog hidden in a plant, a shady Traveller’s palm and newly grown mushrooms - ideal stools for Kip. As they search for a dry, sheltered home for Kip, they see bearded dragon and frilled lizards. After clearing a site at the foot of a tree, they draw a plan and prepare to build it. Music by Nancy Tow. Narrated by Roy Dunlop.
